ygData.msgSnippet: Professor, I should first show my admiration for your great work. I would be very appreciated if you can answer the following questions: 1: Which ODE/DAE

Professor,
I should first show my admiration for your great work.
I would be very appreciated if you can answer the following questions:

1: Which ODE/DAE solver (DASSC, DVODE and DASPK) was adopted by 
cantera for the core chemical kinetical problem dy/dt=F(y,t)? In 
which C++ file (please give the file name) the solver was called?

2: Did you compare the results coming out from cantera with those 
from CHEMKIN III? Or what do you think to use different ODE solvers?
Can we expect the same y vs. t? Indeed when I used MATLAB's ODE15S to 
solve the same problem shown in SENKIN as a example,(20 reaction, 9 
species), I got silent different y vs. t?

3: Since k=k(t,T) and T=T(t), it is difficult to solve large sparse 
DAEs. In my own opinion, (^-^), it is not well known that CHEMKIN III 
adopt the method of infinite difference to divide the time range to 
custom designed number of small ranges and assume the same 
temperature within one small time range and use the previous 
calulated T to compute k in next range. So the DAEs were changed to 
ODE and easier to be solved by DASSC. Of course, it is not a prefect 
method. Can you tell us something about how to handle this kind of 
problem?

Thank you!

Pingping
